content.description: Starting from the top of a nearby boulder (or, alternatively, pursuing a 5.0 chimney), clip the first bolt into a crimpy and difficult start. Vertical crimp management ensues between healthily spaced bolts. The end verges into slightly R arete terrain that is easy.
content.location: Right of the 5.9 crack, BLM Crack, in front of a large boulder.

content.description: A fun technical sport route between The Ranger's a Psycho and Good Enough for Government Work. It shares the anchors with both those routes and you can practically start this route on either of the two mentioned routes, although you are suppose to start it on Good Enough for Government work.
content.location: This route in on the BLM Rock - West Corridor between The Ranger's a Psycho and Good Enough for Government Work. Park at the near campsites 2, 3, and 4 att he base of Twin Sisters. Take the trail between campsite 2 and 3.

content.description: Look for the two bolt above a good sized "bush". This climb starts on small crimpers past two bolts to a finger size crack the rest of the way up.
content.location: This is the third route that you come to on the wall and is the second "crack" from the right. Park at the near campsites 2, 3, and 4 att he base of Twin Sisters. Take the trail between campsite 2 and 3.

content.description: A nice line in a well shaded corridor.  Two obvious crack system begin about 15 feet off the ground. Good Enough for Government Work follows the right hand crack.  Starts with flaky rock and stiff moves before engaging the crack above.
content.protection: 2 bolts and small to medium gear for the crack to a bolted anchor.
content.location: Begin at the huecos and move up on sidepulls and crimps through two bolts.  Continue following the crack up and slightly right past a small ledge and a couple horizontal crack systems.  Reach another ledge and move left to a set of shared anchors.

climbs.name: Do Rangers Dream of Electric Sheep?

content.description:
This little gem deserves more love.  Bingham's guide (2004 version) shows this as more or less as a straight-line and derides it as "contrived" and taking the "line of most resistance," but we climbed the face linking together incipient cracks and horizontals for pro which made for a great climb -- sowewhat reminiscent of the wandering nature of

Beware of Nesting Egos

(albeit shorter and the rock is not as good) and neither contrived nor unreasonably protected.   Done as described here, this is the best 5.10 on the crag IMO.

Start by scrambling up a low-angle pillar-like formation and leaning across to a thin crack that leads to a horizontal.  From here angle right past a bolt (SMC hanger, and it looks like a quarter-inch sleeve bolt, so look for options to back it up) to another thin crack.  From there, angle back left to the chains.
content.protection: Wireds (consider offsets) and cams micro to hand-size; some shoulder length slings.  Chain anchors.
